elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st015">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Presented here is a microporous Mn-based metal–organic framework, which exhibits high selectivity for the adsorption of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> under ambient conditions.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st020">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="o0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Presented here is a microporous formate framework.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The HCOO<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> was in situ generated from the decomposition of DMF.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The desolvated framework shows highly selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Presented here is a microporous formate framework.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The HCOO<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> was in situ generated from the decomposition of DMF.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The desolvated framework shows highly selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st025">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">A metal–organic framework [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·DMF <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> with in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent has been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Infrared Spectroscopy (IR) and Elemental analysis (EA). Each formate ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three octahedral Mn(II) centers to form a neutral three-dimensional (3D) framework with interesting 1D zigzag channel along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, in which the DMF fill the free spaces. The desolvated samples exhibit interesting adsorption properties and show high selectivity for the adsorption of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> under ambient conditions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Presented here is a microporous Mn-based metal–organic framework, which exhibits high selectivity for the adsorption of CO2 over N2 under ambient conditions.





Highlights



•
Presented here is a microporous formate framework.


•
The HCOO- was in situ generated from the decomposition of DMF.


•
The desolvated framework shows highly selective CO2 capture.



Presented here is a microporous formate framework.
The HCOO- was in situ generated from the decomposition of DMF.
The desolvated framework shows highly selective CO2 capture.
Abstract
A metal–organic framework [Mn3(HCOO)6]·DMF (1) with in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent has been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Infrared Spectroscopy (IR) and Elemental analysis (EA). Each formate ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three octahedral Mn(II) centers to form a neutral three-dimensional (3D) framework with interesting 1D zigzag channel along the b axis, in which the DMF fill the free spaces. The desolvated samples exhibit interesting adsorption properties and show high selectivity for the adsorption of CO2 over N2 under ambient conditions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a class of crystalline solid-state material featuring regular and designable channel structures with permanent porosity . Porous MOFs with high surface areas and tunable structures have recently attracted considerable interest not only for their fascinating architectures and intriguing topologies, but also for their potential applications in sensing, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and separation . Flue gases consist of nitrogen (typically more than two-thirds), carbon dioxide, water vapor, oxygen, and minor components such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur oxides. Economical and efficient CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture and storage (CCS) has been attracting tremendous attention due to the culprit for causing the greenhouse effect . Several technologies have been considered for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture and separation from nitrogen-rich streams, including absorption, adsorption and membranes separations . In particular, for separation of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, because of the relatively similar kinetic diameters of the molecules (3.3 and 3.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), it would require materials operating on a size-selective mechanism to possess very small pores, which may limit the diffusion of gases throughout the material. Therefore, to find a suitable pore size material is a necessary condition for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> separation. Herein, we report an compound [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), synthesized by Mn salt and in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of DMF solvent , which exhibits high CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and selectivity of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> under ambient conditions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a class of crystalline solid-state material featuring regular and designable channel structures with permanent porosity . Porous MOFs with high surface areas and tunable structures have recently attracted considerable interest not only for their fascinating architectures and intriguing topologies, but also for their potential applications in sensing, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and separation . Flue gases consist of nitrogen (typically more than two-thirds), carbon dioxide, water vapor, oxygen, and minor components such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur oxides. Economical and efficient CO2 capture and storage (CCS) has been attracting tremendous attention due to the culprit for causing the greenhouse effect . Several technologies have been considered for CO2 capture and separation from nitrogen-rich streams, including absorption, adsorption and membranes separations . In particular, for separation of CO2/N2, because of the relatively similar kinetic diameters of the molecules (3.3 and 3.64Å, respectively), it would require materials operating on a size-selective mechanism to possess very small pores, which may limit the diffusion of gases throughout the material. Therefore, to find a suitable pore size material is a necessary condition for CO2/N2 separation. Herein, we report an compound [Mn3(HCOO)6]·DMF (1), synthesized by Mn salt and in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of DMF solvent , which exhibits high CO2 adsorption and selectivity of CO2 over N2 under ambient conditions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in a monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
. The asymmetric unit contains four crystallographically independent Mn(II) (occupation factor of Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Mn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> is 0.5), six formate anions and one DMF as guest (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). Each formate ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three octahedral Mn(II) centers to form a neutral three-dimensional (3D) framework with interesting 1D zigzag channel along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, in which the DMF fill the free spaces (b). The free solvent accessible pore volume ratio in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is about 30% without considering the DMF guest molecules, as calculated with the PLATON program. The coordination geometry of Mn and formate, as well as the overall framework topology, closely resemble those of the Mn(II) and Co(II) formate that has been reported earlier . Differently, in compound <ce:bold>1,</ce:bold> the HCOO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> generates in situ from the decomposition of DMF and DMF acts as the guest.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group P21/n
. The asymmetric unit contains four crystallographically independent Mn(II) (occupation factor of Mn3 and Mn4 is 0.5), six formate anions and one DMF as guest (
a). Each formate ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three octahedral Mn(II) centers to form a neutral three-dimensional (3D) framework with interesting 1D zigzag channel along the b axis, in which the DMF fill the free spaces (b). The free solvent accessible pore volume ratio in 1 is about 30% without considering the DMF guest molecules, as calculated with the PLATON program. The coordination geometry of Mn and formate, as well as the overall framework topology, closely resemble those of the Mn(II) and Co(II) formate that has been reported earlier . Differently, in compound 1, the HCOO− generates in situ from the decomposition of DMF and DMF acts as the guest.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">To study the thermal behavior of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> were performed on polycrystalline sample to determine its thermal behavior from 25 to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. TGA on the as-synthesized sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicated weight loss of 14.72% before 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponding to the release of solvent (DMF) molecules. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates that the framework is stable up to ca. 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (Fig. S1). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose. We notice that the compound 1 has less thermal stability than that of [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·[1,4-dioxane] reported by Kim et al. . We also check the PXRD patterns between the desolvated and as-synthesized samples, and find that the main peaks of the desolvated one shift to high angles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Interestingly, after immersing in DMF or MeOH again, it will restore to its original look. We deduce that the guest DMF in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is irregular, and has higher boiling point and bigger spatial volume than that of 1,4-dioxane, so the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a little expansion to encapsule big guest molecule and less thermal stability after releasing the guest.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
To study the thermal behavior of compound 1, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 were performed on polycrystalline sample to determine its thermal behavior from 25 to 800°C. TGA on the as-synthesized sample of 1 indicated weight loss of 14.72% before 300°C, which corresponding to the release of solvent (DMF) molecules. The TGA curve of 1 indicates that the framework is stable up to ca. 300°C (Fig. S1). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose. We notice that the compound 1 has less thermal stability than that of [Mn3(HCOO)6]·[1,4-dioxane] reported by Kim et al. . We also check the PXRD patterns between the desolvated and as-synthesized samples, and find that the main peaks of the desolvated one shift to high angles (
). Interestingly, after immersing in DMF or MeOH again, it will restore to its original look. We deduce that the guest DMF in 1 is irregular, and has higher boiling point and bigger spatial volume than that of 1,4-dioxane, so the framework of 1 shows a little expansion to encapsule big guest molecule and less thermal stability after releasing the guest.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The permanent microporosity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> degassed under a dynamic vacuum at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Gas adsorption measurements (N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. The experiments shows typical type I behavior (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), which is characteristic of microporous materials. The maximum N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 28.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (STP). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are estimated to be 78.1 and 113.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake is higher than those for [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·dioxane previously reported at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, mainly due to the flexibility of the framework mentioned above.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The permanent microporosity of 1 degassed under a dynamic vacuum at 160°C for 5h, was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N2 at 77K. Gas adsorption measurements (N2, H2, and CO2) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. The experiments shows typical type I behavior (
), which is characteristic of microporous materials. The maximum N2 uptake at 1bar for 1 is 28.36cm3
g−1 (STP). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas for 1 are estimated to be 78.1 and 113.9m2
g−1, respectively. The N2 uptake is higher than those for [Mn3(HCOO)6]·dioxane previously reported at 77K, mainly due to the flexibility of the framework mentioned above.

other properties: Gas adsorption measurements (N2, H2, and CO2) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer.
The maximum N2 uptake at 1 bar for 1 is 28.36 cm3/g (STP).
The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas for 1 are estimated to be 78.1 and 113.9 m2/g, respectively.
The N2 uptake is higher than those for [Mn3(HCOO)6]·dioxane previously reported at 77K, mainly due to the flexibility of the framework mentioned above.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Considering its low adsorption amount of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and the difference between it and the former reported one, low-pressure hydrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 77 and 87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K were furtherly measured (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a–d). No hysteresis was observed in these isotherms at both temperatures. The adsorption isotherms revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can adsorb 4.29<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and 3.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (75.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 77 and 87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. These results are almost equal to the former one , also suggest that the samples are fully activated. The isosteric heat of adsorption (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf>) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was also calculated. At zero coverage, the <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf> is 6.66<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ/mol (Fig. S3). This value of the isosteric heat of adsorption is moderate compared with the many famous porous materials, such as ZIF-8, MIL-100, PCN-10, HKUST-1, MOF-5, IRMOF-1 and IRMOF-8 .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Considering its low adsorption amount of N2 and the difference between it and the former reported one, low-pressure hydrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms for 1 at 77 and 87K were furtherly measured (
a–d). No hysteresis was observed in these isotherms at both temperatures. The adsorption isotherms revealed that 1 can adsorb 4.29mmolg−1 (96cm3
g−1) and 3.38mmolg−1 (75.6cm3
g−1) of H2 at 77 and 87K, respectively. These results are almost equal to the former one , also suggest that the samples are fully activated. The isosteric heat of adsorption (Q
st) of 1 was also calculated. At zero coverage, the Q
st is 6.66kJ/mol (Fig. S3). This value of the isosteric heat of adsorption is moderate compared with the many famous porous materials, such as ZIF-8, MIL-100, PCN-10, HKUST-1, MOF-5, IRMOF-1 and IRMOF-8 .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Since the samples were fully activated, what attract us is its CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture and storage. The adsorption isotherms of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured up to 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. As shown in e–h, the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake values are 2.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and 1.92<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. The carbon dioxide uptake values of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are higher than that of many famous porous materials at 273 and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively, such as ZIFs, SNUs, MOFs, BIF-9-Li, and MILs (Table S1) . Virial analysis of the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherms revealed that the isosteric heat of adsorption of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at zero surface coverage is 24.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ/mol (Fig. S5). The potential of this rigid framework material in CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas separation was also explored. As shown in i and j, N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was hardly adsorbed at all at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (3.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (3.73<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). We employed the Henry’s constants to estimate the adsorption selectivity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
, which has been shown to be valid for calculating the gas selectivity of MOFs, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is calculated to exhibit an adsorption selectivity of 36.6 for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 25.3 at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K respectively, which indicated that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has excellent CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption selectivity. To our knowledge, these selectivity values are the particularly well reported to date for MOF materials .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Since the samples were fully activated, what attract us is its CO2 capture and storage. The adsorption isotherms of CO2 for 1 were measured up to 1bar at 273K and 298K, respectively. As shown in e–h, the CO2 uptake values are 2.55mmolg−1 (57cm3
g−1) at 273K, and 1.92mmolg−1 (43cm3
g−1) at 298K, respectively. The carbon dioxide uptake values of 1 are higher than that of many famous porous materials at 273 and 298K, respectively, such as ZIFs, SNUs, MOFs, BIF-9-Li, and MILs (Table S1) . Virial analysis of the CO2 adsorption isotherms revealed that the isosteric heat of adsorption of 1 at zero surface coverage is 24.5kJ/mol (Fig. S5). The potential of this rigid framework material in CO2/N2 gas separation was also explored. As shown in i and j, N2 was hardly adsorbed at all at 273K (3.96cm3
g−1) and 298K (3.73cm3
g−1). We employed the Henry’s constants to estimate the adsorption selectivity of 1 for CO2/N2
, which has been shown to be valid for calculating the gas selectivity of MOFs, 1 is calculated to exhibit an adsorption selectivity of 36.6 for CO2 over N2 at 273K and 25.3 at 298K respectively, which indicated that 1 has excellent CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity. To our knowledge, these selectivity values are the particularly well reported to date for MOF materials .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In summary, we report a microporous Mn-formate framework via solvothermal method with in situ generated formate ligand decomposited by DMF solvent. The desolvated framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits high CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and excellent selectivity of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which suggests that this simple framework can also be as the suitable CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture material because of its excellent size-selective effect.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report a microporous Mn-formate framework via solvothermal method with in situ generated formate ligand decomposited by DMF solvent. The desolvated framework of 1 exhibits high CO2 adsorption and excellent selectivity of CO2 over N2 at 273K and 298K, which suggests that this simple framework can also be as the suitable CO2 capture material because of its excellent size-selective effect.

other properties: excellent selectivity of CO2 over N2 at 273K and 298K
